2.heading: B.C. Italian.
2.title: B.C.
2.author: di Hart
2.appears_in: p. 6 in European Newspaper Comic Strips : a survey of 79 strips collected from various European papers dated August 16 to September 10, 1968 (collection assembled in the Michigan State University Comic Art Collection).
notes: This strip taken from Paese Sera (Rome) (Aug. 19, 1968).
B.C., dated May 21, 1968, in Italian.

3.heading: B.C.--Articles About.
3.title: "Use Comic Strip to Boost Understanding"
3.author: Charles C
3.appears_in: Haynes. p. 6D in the Lansing State Journal, May 5, 2001.
notes: Article about Johnny Hart's B.C. strip for Easter Sunday.

4.heading: B.C.--Articles About.
4.title: "Zot! The King is a Fink!"
4.author: by Richard Sherry
4.appears_in: p. 24-33 in The World of Comic Art, v. 2, no. 1 (Summer 1967).
notes: On Wizard of Id and B.C., with photographs of Johnny Hart and Brant Parker and samples of both strips.
Includes a cast of characters for B.C.

5.heading: B.C.--Exhibitions.
5.title: "The Art and Humor of Johnny Hart" p. 32-35 in Cartoonist Profiles, no. 108
5.author: [No author]
notes: Illustrated account of a Johnny Hart/B.C. exhibit at the Roberson Museum & Science Center (Binghamton, N.Y.) until June 1996.

6.heading: B.C.--Miscellanea.
6.title: B.C.
6.author: by Johnny Hart
6.appears_in: Entry on p. 4 in These Top Cartoonists (Fort Lauderdale, Fla. : Allied Publications, 1964).
notes: Entries are a page of text, a photograph of the artist, a drawing of the main character and a sample strip or panel.

7.heading: B.C.--Miscellanea.
7.title: "B.C. Strips Pulled from LA Times" p. 22 in The Comics Journal, no. 186
7.author: [No author]

8.heading: B.C.--Miscellanea.
8.title: The Blank in the Comics strip collection includes a file of one or more daily comic strips related to this keyword or topic. Call no.: PN6726 f.B55
8.author: [No author]

9.heading: B.C.--Miscellanea.
9.title: "Comics Offer a Forum for Issues of Our Times"
9.author: by Shelvia Dancy
9.appears_in: Religion News Service article in The Plain Dealer (Cleveland, Ohio), May 23, 2001.
notes: Based on interviews with Leonard Greenspoon of Creighton University, Lucy Caswell of Ohio State University, and Mike Morgan, creator of the strip "For Heaven's Sake!". Mentions religious themes and clergy in B.C., Beetle Bailey, Kudzu, The Family Circus, Frank and Ernest, and Peanuts.

10.heading: B.C.--Miscellanea.
10.title: "Danger, Pictures Ahead"
10.author: by R
10.appears_in: C. Harvey. p. 100-106 in The Comics Journal, no. 242 (Apr. 2002).
notes: (Comicopia)
On stories without words, on people taking offense at pictures, and particularly on people's reactions to Johnny Hart's religious B.C. strips, and other religious content in comics and cartoons.

48.heading: B.D.
48.title: "B.D., Do You Realize Our Lives are Peaking Tonight?"
48.author: by Garry Trudeau.
notes: Summary: Boopsie and B.D. are in a limo on the way to see the President, while the President has his people cancelling the visit and sending an autographed picture. Boopsie is in a $3,000 dress.

49.heading: B.D.
49.title: "I Feel Like a Leprechaun"
49.author: G
49.appears_in: B. Trudeau. reproduced on p. 129 of Golf in the Comic Strips, ed. by Howard Ziehm (General Publishing Group, 1997).
notes: Summary: Zonker wins the tanning award, and thanks George Hamilton and all the little people who've supported him. Mark and B.D. don't particularly like being called little people.

50.heading: B.D.
50.title: "I Fixed the Lawn Mower"
50.author: G
notes: Summary: Boopsie is worried how hurt and threatened B.D. is going to be when he finds out what she's done.

51.heading: B.D.
51.title: "So Is That a Bleach Job, or What?"
51.author: G
notes: Summary: B.D. goes on about football, until Boopsie tries to get him to change the subject.

52.heading: B.D.
52.title: "Well, You Didn't Have to Keep the Motor Running!"
52.author: G
notes: Summary: Boopsie sends B.D. packing, and he comes back to the car with his suitcase and golf clubs.

160.heading: BP Books, Inc.
160.title: Spider-Man : Secret of the Sinister Six
160.author: by Adam-Troy Castro ; interior illustrations by Mike Zeck.
notes: Summary (from OCLC): The Gentleman has been the secret mastermind of wars and acts of crime around the world, including the murder of Peter Parker's parents. Years ago, the Gentleman discovered that Peter Parker is secretly Spider-Man. He brainwashed Peter's long-lost sister and turned her into the super-villainess known as Pity. A new Sinister Six (The Gentleman, Pity, Doctor Octopus, Electro, the Vulture, and Mysterio) will enact the final act of vengeance
destroy Peter Parker!
